conclusion: To express van der Waals constants a and b in terms of critical temperature Tc and critical pressure Pc, use critical point conditions for van der Waals equation.
Van der Waals equation is given by (P + a/V^2)(V - b) = RT.
At the critical point, first derivative of pressure with respect to volume is zero.
At the critical point, second derivative of pressure with respect to volume is zero.
Pressure at the critical point is Pc.
Express van der Waals equation in terms of P: P = RT/(V - b) - a/V^2.
First derivative of P with respect to V: ∂P/∂V = -RT/(V - b)^2 + 2a/V^3.
Set first derivative equal to zero at critical point: -RTc/(Vc - b)^2 + 2a/Vc^3 = 0.
Second derivative of P with respect to V: ∂^2P/∂V^2 = 2RT/(V - b)^3 - 6a/V^4.
Set second derivative equal to zero at critical point: 2RTc/(Vc - b)^3 - 6a/Vc^4 = 0.
Solve for a: a = RTc Vc^3/(2(Vc - b)^2).
Substitute a into second equation: RTc Vc^4 = 3(RTc Vc^3/(2(Vc - b)^2)) (Vc - b)^3.
Cancel RTc Vc^3 from both sides: Vc = 3(Vc - b)/2.
Substitute b back into expression for a: a = RTc Vc^3/(2(2Vc/3)^2).
